text:
SPEAKER: Can you
talk a little bit

about the issue of the portrayal
of women in Indian cinema

and how you have seen this
change over time, for better
or for worse?

And do you think that
the industry, in general,

is conscious enough of
the social impact it
has in this respect?

SHYAM BENEGAL: Well,
I mean, cinema,

essentially, we have always
been a patriarchal society.
We have always felt--

I'm talking of conventionally,
traditionally--

that a woman's
place is in a home.

She is supposed to be a
daughter, wife, mother.
She has a place.
Her kingdom is the home.

Her job is to be a dutiful
daughter, a faithful wife,
a giving mother.
This is her job.

And if she fulfills those,
then she is like a goddess.
Now, this is traditional view.

Now, in a situation
like this, what happens

is, how does this
work with equality?

When you have put a woman
into that kind of situation,

what is it that will make
her equal to a man, a male?

Because if it's a
question of equality,

what the male has
by way of rights

should be the
rights of the woman,

as well, which is what the
Constitution promises us.

If that is the case, then
if tradition does this,

then you have to get
rid of that tradition.

But it's very
difficult to do that.
Now, cinema in India--

because you see, in the
popular mind, popular view,

which is, actually, always
a traditional view--

so they accept woman in
tradition very easily.

So it's very easy to put that
kind of figure into the cinema

and make it acceptable
for the audience.

Because they will automatically
accept a person like that,
a woman like that.

But if that is challenged,
then you have problems.

Now, one of the
things, in my case,

was to constantly challenge that
notion from the very beginning,

whether it was Ankur,
whether it was Nishant,

whether it was Manthan,
whether it was Bhumika,
whether it was Mandi.
Look at any one of my films.
It's always been that way.

Because for me, equality, that's
more important than having-- so
the traditional view has to go.

Because otherwise, there
will be no equality.

There will be no real
democracy, either.
So it's important to do that.

And cinema is one of the areas
where you should be doing it
all the time.

Really, it's not--
because some people

think that you
create a woman who's
a kind of avenging figure.
That's not equality.

But they will just
say, oh, this is what
establishes women's rights.
I think that's utter nonsense.
That's not how it is.

So the sense of equality has
been very, very important

to my own view of life,
of our society, and so on.

It's very important
that we recognize this.

But it's very difficult
to recognize it

because we continue to be
a very patriarchal system.

I mean, the world is, more
or less, very patriarchal,
but we are particularly so.

Because there's a
traditional stamp on it.
They say, this is right.
This is how it should be.

Because historically, also,
it is correct and so on.

So you have to keep
fighting it all the time.
